body.p:
Your letter of the 20th of Iyar (May),
which came to me by way of Magdeburg,
delighted me all the more in that I saw in it
your warm family devotion and especially your
interest and concern and love for me.

Were I still unmarried I would,
without further thought, consent to your
request to obtain for myself the position at
San Francisco. I would also and aside from
the success or failure of this plan, gladly
have accepted your invitation to make a
holiday trip to you. This I could have
done without losing my position here, for it
would have given me great pleasure to spend
some time with a beloved relative, whose name
has become famous far off, and who has
accomplished worthwhile things in America in
the interests of our holy faith. However,
since about a year ago I am happily married
and I must take into consideration the
wishes of my beloved wife and not journey

with her quite so far away to a place from
which she would presumably not have the
opportunity again to see her aged parents.

But even if I cannot take into consider
ation the problematical position, nevertheless, I
can answer your questions with regard to a friend
who has ambitions of that sort. His name
is David Steinberg, and he is, at the present
time, teacher in the Jewish seminary at Münster.
The day before yesterday he paid me a visit. From
two letters of his friend Guttheim, I noticed
that the latter recently paid you a visit,
furthermore, that he asked Steinberg to
take steps with regard to the position in San
Francisco. He asked me, therefore, to let you
know request of you to send a word of
recommendation for him to that place.
Steinberg has, in addition to a decided philo
logical bent, devoted to a thorough study of the
classics. At this very time he is about to take his
doctoral examination. He told me that he is
thoroughly acquainted with the French language
& English, however, he has not made any further
progress than to understand the “Vicar of
Wakefield” without having done much further

reading. With his thorough philological
knowledge, however it will not be difficult for him to) make great
progress in this respect. The chief thing, however,
is that it was always his great desire he
is now 34 years old—to devote himself to
the education of the young. In all the com-
munities in which he acted as teacher, until
now, as well as in all his general relationships,
he has enjoyed general respect and love,
both with regard to his thoroughness as well
as his honorable moral character. As regards
religious and ceremonial life, his present
position insures that he lead a ceremonial-
ly Jewish life, if only not to suffer criticism.
Nevertheless, I don't want to overlook the
fact that in this respect he inclines towards
* a mild reform. However, in matters that
concern the fundamentals of our holy
faith, I can safely say that, in so far as I can
judge human beings, that he is a Jew with
a sincerely Jewish heart.

Steinberg thinks that if it is possible he
would prefer that another man be given the
position of chazan while he devote himself to
preaching and religious instruction of the
young. This he desires, not because he lacks

the aptitude for such work but because the
combination of all these activities in one person, es-
pecially in so large a community, might be too
exhausting. He would gladly give up a portion of
his salary if a chazan were appointed separately.

In the year 1851, the second part of my
Hebrew study and exercise book appeared. I sent it
to you through an emigrant but I don't know
whether it has been delivered to you. The reviews,
of this book, seem very favorable. It is also
having a seemingly good sale. Although it
was written originally for Jewish schools, it has been
introduced also in some German
gymnasia. Unfortunately, a large number
of our Jewish teachers are either too ignorant of
Hebrew or too indifferent to make practical use
of this book. On the other hand, some highly re-
spected and excellent colleagues have let
me know by letter that since the introduction of
my book in their schools, the instruction in
Hebrew has taken a new upward swing and
has caused a made Hebrew a popular subject, on the
part of the spiritually awakened children. Such
men, however, are exceptional, for most
Jewish teachers are merely “hewers of wood
in the house of God.” They limit them-
selves to the most essential. Generally
speaking, Hebrew teaching is torture for
them, since they themselves are ignorant

of it. Most guilty is the “Münstersche Ver-*
einschule” which does not produce sufficient
results in this respect, and in spite of the en-
closed program of studies which has been
acclaimed throughout the classes of the com-
munity, it has not until now, improved
any. The chief fault lies in the unsatisfactory
method of the good, but elderly, seminary
teacher, Cohen, who has no understanding
of how an interest for such studies can be
planted in his pupils.

For our needy brothers in Palestine,
collections have been taken up rather diligently
here also. Dülmen for example contributed
18 ½ Reichstaler.

Finally, several family news items.
Lippman is married since 1847. Selig
since a year ago. The former has four
children. Both conduct a business in corn
in —?, which is really flourishing.
Probka is, for the last five years, married
to one of the most important — in Essen,
Jamgon Gottschelk, and has four children.
Hindlke, who three years ago married the
oldest son of Uncle Isaac, in Lünen, un-
fortunately died in childbirth. The little
son which she left, is thank God, in good
health. Zanvil has a good
medical practice in Herzfeld,

near Loest? Lazar and Gittlesche are
still in the old peoples' home. My dear
mother is, thank God, still in good health,
and is at present on a visit at Procha's.
Everyone sends you hearty greetings. I
am very happy with my beloved wife
Shanetta. She is very religious, kind-
hearted, and a good housekeeper. In spite
of our meager income she knows how to
manage so that we get along very nicely
in a respectable manner of living. In
order to improve our situation, I intend
to establish a store, which my wife, who is
used to such things from her home, will
have in charge.

And now, my dear cousin, write it is
your turn to write to me about your private
situation. A short while ago I heard you
had given up your position. Is that really
so? Good luck, many blessings to you
and your work. With unchangeable, loyal
friendship and love, I remain, your cousin
